facts.text: Occurrence took place at about 11-30 p.m. on November 10, 1955 at Muthupet in front of tea stall of Kannuswami.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence which was the subject-matter of the charges against the two appellants took place at about 11-30 p.m. on November 10, 1955, at Muthupet, in front of the tea stall of Kannuswami,

facts.text: Kannuswami is husband of Shrimati Dhanabagyam, prosecution witness No. 1, principal witness.

facts.text: Two appellants rushed into tea stall premises, old man ran away, dragged Kannuswami out and first appellant gave several blows on chest with aruval.

anchor.surface_text: When Kannuswami got busy preparing the tea, the two appellants rushed into the premises. The old man-the intending customer-naturally ran away, and the two accused dragged Kannuswami out of the shop

facts.text: Kannuswami fell down on back and cried for help, wife put his head in lap after accused left.

anchor.surface_text: on to the road-side and the first appellant gave him several blows on the front part of his body in the region of the chest with an aruval-a cutting instrument about 2 feet long including the handle.

facts.text: Accused returned, first appellant made body face downwards and gave cuts on head, neck and back causing instantaneous death.

issues.text: Whether the conviction and sentences of the appellants should be upheld given that they rest solely on the testimony of the first witness, the widow of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of conviction and sentence, as passed by the courts below, as indicated above, rest solely on the testimony of the first witness. It has been argued by the learned counsel for the appellants that the conviction and sentences of the appellants should not, be upheld because they rest on the sole testimony of the first witness, particularly, because, it is further argued, her testimony is not free from all blemish.

issues.text: Whether there was a material contradiction in the first witness's testimony between her statement in the committing court (Exhibit D-2) and her testimony in the Sessions Court regarding which accused inflicted the cut injuries.

anchor.surface_text: She has been cross- examined with reference to her statement Exhibit D-2 recorded by the committing Magistrate, and she has categorically stated Accused 1 had no weapon of any kind with him. He did not give any cut. I have not stated in the committing court that accused 1 continued to cut even after Shanmugham Thevar asked him not to cut.

issues.text: Whether it is safe to convict the appellants on the testimony of a single witness even though she may not have been demonstrated to be a lying witness, and whether corroboration is required as a rule of law or only as a rule of prudence.

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, it has been argued on behalf of the appellants that it is not safe to convict the appellants on the testimony of a single witness even though she may not have been demonstrated to have been a lying witness. It has not even been claimed by counsel for the appellants that this is a rule of law. He has only put it on the ground of prudence that, ordinarily, the court should not, in a case involving a charge of murder, convict an accused person upon the testimony of a single witness.

issues.text: Whether the court should not impose the extreme penalty of death and instead award the lesser sentence, given that the conviction rests on the testimony of a single witness.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was urged that assuming that the court was inclined to act upon the testimony of the first witness and to record a conviction for murder as against the first appellant, the court should not impose the extreme penalty of law and in the state of the record as it is, the lesser punishment provided by law should be deemed to meet the ends of justice.

issues.text: Whether the nature and volume of evidence affects the quantum of sentence in a murder case, or whether sentence is determined by the circumstances of the crime and presence of extenuating factors.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which the court has to consider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the court, to have committed the crime. If the court is convinced about the truth of the prosecution story, conviction has to follow. The question of sentence has to be determined, not with reference to the volume or character of the evidence adduced by the prosecution in support of the prosecution case, but with reference to the fact whether there are any extenuating circumstances which can be said to mitigate the enormity of the crime.

arguments.claim: Conviction and sentences should not be upheld because they rest solely on the testimony of the first witness which is not free from all blemish

holdings.text: The recording of the first witness's statement in Exhibit D-2 by the committing Magistrate was defective, with accused 1 recorded in place of accused 2; her testimony was consistent throughout that accused 2 inflicted the injuries.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the statement of the first witness, as recorded in Exhibit D-2, the learned Sessions Judge has observed that it was a mistake of recording by the committing Magistrate. We have looked into the whole evidence of the first witness, as recorded by the committing Magistrate-not printed in the record, but supplied to us by the learned counsel for the appellants-and in our opinion, there is nodoubt that the learned Sessions Judge was correct in his conclusion that the recording by the Magistrate is defective in the sense that accused 1 has been recorded in place of accused 2,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deposition consistent attributing injuries to A2; not challenged in lower appeals; Sessions Judge finding correct.

holdings.text: The first witness's testimony is reliable, rings true as a whole, and court has no hesitation in acting upon it without corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: Her evidence, read as a whole, rings quite true, and we have no hesitation in acting upon it. It is true that her evidence in court has been sought to be contradicted by the evidence of P.Ws. 2 to 4, but the latter set of witnesses have been shown to be not reliable because they appear to have made different statements at different stages for reasons of their own.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Frank admissions on deceased's past; consistent with FIR (prompt), medical evidence (double attack); other PW hostile/unreliable.

holdings.text: As a general rule, a court can and may act on the testimony of a single witness though uncorroborated; one credible witness outweighs many indifferent ones; corroboration not required by law except as prudence in child/accomplice cases.

anchor.surface_text: Section 134 of the Indian Evidence Act has categorically laid it down that no particular number of witnesses shall in any case be required for the proof of any fact. The legislature determined, as long ago as 1872, presumably after due consideration of the pros and cons, that it shall not be necessary for proof or disproof of a fact, to call any particular number of witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.134 Evidence Act; distinguishes Privy Council (child unsworn), Vemireddy (accomplice-like); quality over quantity; legislative intent against plurality rule.

holdings.text: No legal impediment to convicting on entirely reliable single witness testimony; court must act if satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: If such a testimony is found by the court to be entirely reliable, there is no legal impediment to the conviction of the accused person on such proof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of general rule to facts; PW1 wholly reliable category.

holdings.text: Conviction and death sentence under s.302 IPC upheld for first appellant based on PW1 testimony.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no reasons to refuse to act upon the testimony of the first witness, which is the only reliable evidence in support of the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PW1 reliable; applies single witness rule; cold-blooded murder.

holdings.text: Sentence determined by circumstances of crime and extenuating factors, not by volume or nature of evidence; death upheld as no mitigation in cold-blooded murder.

anchor.surface_text: The question of sentence has to be determined, not with reference to the volume or character of the evidence adduced by the prosecution in support of the prosecution case, but with reference to the fact whether there are any extenuating circumstances which can be said to mitigate the enormity of the crime.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proof goes to guilt only; here deliberate second assault, no extenuation.

holdings.text: Second appellant's conviction under s.326 IPC and 5 years sentence upheld (implicitly, as appeal directed against it but no reversal).

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second appellant, we need not say anything more than that he was lucky enough to escape conviction under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code, for the reasons given by the High Court, which may not bear close scrutiny. He amply deserves the punishment of 5 years rigorous imprisonment under s.326 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court modification accepted; aiding role justifies grievous hurt.

precedents.citation: Mohamed Sugal Esa Mamasan Rer Alalah v. The, King 1

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection, our attention was drawn to the observations of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in the case of Mohamed Sugal Esa Mamasan Rer Alalah v. The, King  1 . In that case, their Lordships looked for companyroboration of the testimony of a single witness in a murder case. It is true that in that case, the court had to look for and found companyroboration of the testimony of the single witness in support of the murder charge, but the testimony of that witness suffered from two infirmities, namely (1) The witness was a girl of about 10 or 11 years at the time of occurrence. (2) The girl witness had number been administered oath because the Court did number companysider that she was able to understand the nature of the oath though she was companypetent to testify.

precedents.case_name: Mohamed Sugal Esa Mamasan Rer Alalah v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: It is a sound rule in practice not to act on the uncorroborated evidence of a child, whether sworn or unsworn, but this is a rule of prudence and not of law
precedents.cited_holding: Once there is admissible evidence a court can act upon it; corroboration, unless required by statute, goes only to the weight and value of the evidence. It is a sound rule in practice not to act on the uncorroborated evidence of a child, whether sworn or unsworn, but this is a rule of prudence and not of law.

precedents.citation: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy and three others v. The State of Hyderabad 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in the case of Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy and three others v. The State of Hyderabad 1  was also relied upon in support of the contention that in a murder case the court insists on corroboration of the testimony of a single witness. In the said reported decision of this Court, P.W. 14 has been described as a dhobi boy named Gopai. He was the only person who had witnessed the murder and his testimony had been assailed on the ground that he was an accomplice. Though this Court repelled the contention that he was an accomplice, it held that his position was analogous to that of an accomplice.

precedents.case_name: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy and three others v. The State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: Court insists on corroboration of the testimony of a single witness in a murder case where the witness's position is analogous to that of an accomplice
precedents.cited_holding: Though he was not an accomplice, we would still want corroboration on material particulars in this particular case, as he is the only witness to the crime and as it would be unsafe to hang four people on his sole testimony unless we feel convinced that he is speaking the truth.

justification_sets.label: Conviction on Single Witness Testimony support

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was urged that assuming that the companyrt was inclined to act upon the testimony of the first witness and to record a companyviction for murder as against the first appellant, the companyrt should number impose the extreme penalty of law and in the state of the record as it is, the lesser punishment provided by law should be deemed to meet the ends of justice. We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the companyrt has to companysider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the companyrt, to have companymitted the crime.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the statement of the first witness, as recorded in Exhibit D-2, the learned Sessions Judge has observed that it was a mistake of recording by the committing Magistrate. We have looked into the whole evidence of the first witness, as recorded by the committing Magistrate-not printed in the record, but supplied to us by the learned counsel for the appellants-and in our opinion, there is nodoubt that the learned Sessions Judge was correct in his conclusion that the recording by the Magistrate is defective in the sense that accused 1 has been recorded in place of accused 2,

Lastly, it was urged that assuming that the companyrt was inclined to act upon the testimony of the first witness and to record a companyviction for murder as against the first appellant, the companyrt should number impose the extreme penalty of law and in the state of the record as it is, the lesser punishment provided by law should be deemed to meet the ends of justice. We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the companyrt has to companysider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the companyrt, to have companymitted the crime.

anchor.surface_text: Section 134 of the Indian Evidence Act has categorically laid it down that no particular number of witnesses shall in any case be required for the proof of any fact. The legislature determined, as long ago as 1872, presumably after due consideration of the pros and cons, that it shall not be necessary for proof or disproof of a fact, to call any particular number of witnesses.

Lastly, it was urged that assuming that the companyrt was inclined to act upon the testimony of the first witness and to record a companyviction for murder as against the first appellant, the companyrt should number impose the extreme penalty of law and in the state of the record as it is, the lesser punishment provided by law should be deemed to meet the ends of justice. We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the companyrt has to companysider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the companyrt, to have companymitted the crime.
